awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Using protein function prediction to promote hypothesis-driven thinking in undergraduate biochemistry education
awd_abstract_narration:
Recognizing the national need for significant improvement in undergraduate STEM education, collaborators from six institutions (Rochester Institute of Technology, St. Mary's University, Oral Roberts University, Hope College, Ursinus College, and California Polytechnic University) will explore a new approach to introduce students to authentic research in biochemistry laboratory courses.  The project will test the hypotheses that engaging in authentic research will improve students' abilities to master key aspects of experimentation (experimental design, data processing and interpretation, and communication of research outcomes) and visualization (use of representations to communicate various aspects of the research process).  The project is likely to be transferrable to other institutions, and is an example of a cost-effective way to introduce course-based research into the undergraduate curriculum.

Biochemistry laboratory courses will be redesigned to include modules in which students will integrate computational and wet lab techniques as they characterize proteins whose three dimensional structures are known but to which functions have not been previously ascribed.  Because the project is focused on discovery, it is reasonable to expect that some of the students will produce novel results that will contribute to the field of biochemistry.  Formative and summative evaluation will address assessment of student learning gains in terms of improved conceptual understanding and visualization of experiments using a validated instrument composed of open-ended and closed-ended questions.  Faculty members and teaching assistants will be surveyed and interviewed about their satisfaction with the project, its usability, and the extent to which they see the project as part of their own and their students' development.  The project team will create and disseminate modules (promol.org) that form the core of a new curriculum for undergraduate biochemistry laboratory courses.  The results of the work will be presented at professional meetings, such as the American Society of Biochemistry and Molecular Biology, and submitted to scholarly journals.

por.por_cntn:
The two-year collaboration involved teachers from five universities with Rochester Institute of Technology taking the lead. Oral Roberts University (ORU) was one of the universities. We are a small (4,000 students) university graduating approximately 35 biology and 10 chemistry majors each year. We offer the BSc degree but no Masters or PhD. We offer students a 3-credit biochemistry lecture (three one-hour lectures per week for 15 weeks) and a 1-credit biochemistry laboratory (one three-hour laboratory per week for 15 weeks). The biochemistry course is taught by chemistry faculty within the Department of Biology and Chemistry. Most of our students are pre-health profession (premed, predent, prevet) majors who are not planning becoming research scientists. 

The purpose of the biochemistry lab at ORU has been teaching lab skills common in biochemistry. The goal has not been to put students into problem solving in a research-type, discovery scenario. Time limitations and reagent/equipment costs tend to preclude this approach. No computer modelling of protein structure-function relationships has been employed until this project.  Our pedagogy has been to present the lab technique to students one-week prior to the actual lab and then on the day of the lab to review the skill in a brief prelab. Students work in pairs and often share equipment. 

The content of the biochemistry lab course prior to this project focused on verification experiments. The experiments involved buffer preparation, amino acid separations by ion-exchange and paper chromatography, optical activity of carbohydrates, enzyme isolation from tissue and enzyme purification using size exclusion and affinity chromatography, enzyme quantification, and enzyme activity assays using a 96-well plate reader.

The current NSF project has resulted in numerous outcomes:

1.   The collaboration between faculty at the different institutions has helped us develop lab teaching modules that are more likely to work the first time which is an enormous benefit to faculty at a small school where lab course develop can be difficult due to high teaching loads and limited numbers of lab staff.

2.   The project has resulted in teaching modules in key areas of: computer modeling of structure-function relationships, plasmid isolation and purification, recombinant DNA modification of a competent cell line, protein expression, protein isolation, protein purification, protein quantification, and enzyme activity assay.

3.   The project has resulted in establishing working relationships among the collaborators. Being able to text or email a fellow collaborator to ask a question about best practices has led to rapid faculty development.

4.   The project has provided a teaching platform that remains skill oriented but has helped us, as a small non-PhD school, to give students a research oriented experience. We are not only teaching techniques but techniques that lead to results that are part of a larger quest, the quest to determine the function of a real protein. We have moved from verification only labs to biochemistry research all in a non-research environment. Students experience research guided and productive sequence, something even pre-health majors appreciate.

5.   We now introduce students to computer modeling of enzyme structures and active-site analysis. ProMol, PyMol, Dali, BLAST, pFam and other programs are giving our students experience with structure-function relationships that were previously not in our biochemistry lab curriculum.

6.   During the first year of the project lab modules were developed and three biochemistry students at ORU used the modules to investigate the function of two proteins, 4DIU and 3DS8. They presented their research in a poster-session at the Spring 2016 American Chemical Society Pentasectional Meeting in Bartlesville, Oklahoma.

7.   During the Fall of 2016 the project the lab modules were used with a biochemistry lab class, CHE 459 Biochemistry Lab. Twelve students working in groups of 2-3 worked on 4 proteins of unknown function. They presented their research results at the end of the semester in PowerPoint presentations which were videotaped. They were also interviewed as part of a post-lab debriefing that was also videotaped. In the videos, they expressed what they liked about the lab and where they saw room for improvement.

8.   During the Spring of 2017 a small biochemistry lab class of 4 students plus 4 Senior Research students continued the research on two of the protein examined in the Fall. By building on the results of other students learned the progressive nature of research. The enzyme recoveries and activities were greater than the Fall class.

9.  As a result of the project we now incorporate more DNA manipulations into the biochemisatry lab. This has helped our chemistry majors who often do not take genetics or immunology.
